titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-1017, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Four gospels in Armenian. Section numbers in the margins against the text. Concordance numbers in the lower margins. Pentecostal lection numbers. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Arm. 54.
The foliation cited in this description is in the lower margin.
4 full-page miniatures of the Evangelists Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John, and portrait busts of Eusebius, Bishop of Caesarea. Marginal vignettes of arabesques, flowers, birds, and temples.

canonTables.p: Citations of concordant gospel sections framed with architectural columns of foliate and geometric motifs. The columns are topped with capitals in the form of masks, animal heads, birds, and busts of the apostles, and support headpieces of multi-colored floral and geometric design. The copy of Eusebius's letter to Carpianus is similarly displayed (fols. 1v-2r).

headpieces.p: Headpieces of multi-colored floral, geometric, and foliate design at gospel openings (fols. 13r, 105r, 162r, 258r). The headpiece of Luke's gospel contains 3 portrait busts in circular frames.

initials.p: The major initial of each gospel's opening line is formed by an Evangelist symbol: Matthew (angel, 75 mm), Mark (winged lion, 62 mm), Luke (ox, 85 mm), and John (eagle, 109 mm). Minor initials formed by figures of birds, and flowers, beads and leaves.

physDesc.extent: 334 leaves, of which 4 are flyleaves. A folded parchment leaf of a 10th century manuscript functions as 2 of the back flyleaves. Written in erkat’agir script, it contains the text of Luke 19:5-17.

foliation.p: 1 (unfoliated paper flyleaf) + 148 + 1 (148[b]) + 141 + 1 (290[b]) + 39 + 2 (unfoliated parchment flyleaves) + 1 (detached unfoliated paper flyleaf). Modern foliation in Arabic numerals in pencil 1-329. Leaves overlooked during foliation numbered 148[b] and 290[b].

physDesc.dimensions: Written space 150 x 100 mm (fol. 44r). Each column is 150 x 45 mm with a space of 10 mm between.

layout.p: 2 columns, 21 lines. Frame ruling in ink.

handDesc.p: Written chiefly in bolorgir script in black ink. The first through third lines of each gospel's opening are inscribed in capitals embellished with beads and leaves, bird letters, or erkat’agir script.

binding.p: Bound in brown leather over boards. Fore-edge flap. Nail holes front and back. Doublures of rose silk.

decoNote.p: Front cover: Blind-tooled flower of four petals within a circle; outer border filled with stamped florets. Back cover: Tooled six-pointed star within same border; outline of a cross once attached.

origin.p: The manuscript was written in 1624 (Armenian Era 1073) by the scribe Step‛anos, at the Church of the Holy Theotokos (Surb Astuacacin) and the Church of the Holy Forty Martyrs (Surb K‛ařasunk‛) in Berea, the present-day Aleppo, Syria.

Archbishop Nahapet administered the sale of the manuscript in Edessa, the present-day Şanlıurfa, Turkey. It was purchased by the mahtesi Grigor, son of Poghos and T‛urvantay, who offered it as his memorial to the Church of the Holy Theotokos (Surb Astuacacin) and to the Church of St. John the Baptist (Surb Karapet) at Karmunch, a village near Edessa. The colophon was written at Karmunch, Friday, August 27, 1624.

provenance.p: Late 17th to mid-20th century provenance unknown. Partially illegible inscription (fol. 3r). University of Chicago Libraries bookplate (front flyleaf).

acquisition.p: Acquired by the University of Chicago in 1947 from the estate of H. M. Tashjian of Chicago.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

msItem.summary: Eusebius of Caesarea (ca. 260-ca. 340), letter to Carpianus, on the gospel canons.
Pericope: The Woman taken in Adultery.

overview.p: 4 full-page miniatures of the Evangelists Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John, and portrait busts of Eusebius, Bishop of Caesarea. Marginal vignettes of arabesques, flowers, birds, and temples.

minItem.minDesc: Eusebius, Bishop of Caesarea, Palestine: Portrait. Facing images of Eusebius; at the left, he holds an open scroll, and at the right, a stylus.
Evangelist, Matthew: Portrait. Matthew reading, seated in high-backed chair; buildings in background.
Evangelist, Mark: Portrait. Mark holding a book, seated in high-backed chair; dove of the Holy Spirit next to his ear; two apostles stand behind him, pointing to dove; building in background.
Evangelist, Luke: Portrait. Luke, seated high-backed chair, hands tablet to Theophilus, at right, the dedicatee of his gospel. Apostles wait behind Luke; buildings in background.
Evangelist, John: Portrait. John stands at right, dove of Holy Spirit near his ear. He dictates to deacon Prochorus, seated at left writing on tablet with stylus; cave in background.
